title: How many total confirmed cases of COVID-19 in China will the World Health Organization (WHO) report as of 20 August 2020?

At this point we would need an average of 273 new confirmed cases per day to reach bucket 4. This seems unlikely given that as of today the three-day average of new confirmed cases is 111 and the seven-day average is 116. Moreover, the 273 figure has only been exceeded *once* in the past few months — this occurred on 31 July, when there were 276 new cases.

20th August is 11 days away. There are already more than 88,000 cases but 2,849 less than 92,000. We need 259 or more cases a day to reach that by then. The current daily case rate is less than this for the last 2 weeks. The number of new cases per day is slowing after a slight increase at the end of July. Seems close but unlikely.
Currently on pace for just under 91,000 based on daily average new cases since 7/30.

The average needed is well over 200 per day now, and current average running at about 100ish.  So to exceed 92k it would need at least a few days of very high numbers reports, which is completely inconsistent with what has happened previously.  Full forecast on bin 3.

Over the last 14 days, china has been averaging 168 cases per day. In order to hit 92,000 by 8/20, China needs to record 208 cases per day. The standard deviation over the last 14 days has been 52. Using this as a daily volatility figure, we can model the probability of reaching 92000 assuming a normal distribution of results around the constant rate of 170/day.

8/3/2020 Update: China reported over 88k infections so lowering probability to 0 for < 88k and 100% for 88k to 92k. Seems unlikely to have another 4k infections by Aug 20. Total infection numbers are then 88,122 + 400 = 88,500 so well below 92k.

Reaffirming figures (until further notice...) The count may end up at 91,500 on 20 August 2020, which is around two daily counts lower than the threshold. Close, and not very comfortable, but the desirable outcome for HK and China.

Right now the great unknown is what will be the size of the Hong Kong outbreak. The analysis of the second outbreak in March/April indicates that once the peak was reached, the number of cases decreased very fast. In fact the highest number of weekly new cases was reached on April 1, and it was 355 cases per week (with a total of 766 cases). Then it decrease by a factor of 0.5 per week. From how geometric series work, this means that the total number of cases after the second wave finished would have been: 766 + 355 = 1121 which slightly overestimates the plateau at the end of the second wave, which was closer to 1050-1100 total cases. Right now we have 594 cases per week: if the third peak has the same structure as the second, and if it stopped today, it will add another 600 cases, and we will end up with about 87000 cases for all of China according to WHO (bar smaller outbreaks in Chinese cities, which "miraculously" will never exceed 100 to 200 cases). However each day in which we have not reach the peak just increases the lower bound of total cases for the 20 of August. Probably if the peak is not reached within one week, it would be really difficult to avoid the 88K bucket. If the peak is reached before, it will be difficult to reach 88K. So it will be mostly decided during the next week.

6/15/20
According the WHO, there are 85,623 total confirmed cases of the Novel Coronavirus in China. The virus emerged in the Hubei province of China in December, causing a province lockdown in early 2020. However, Wuhan exited its full lockdown in March, and since then, daily cases totals have been minimal in the country. According to the Chinese, the spread of the virus was fully contained, and 90%+ of the cases occurred near Wuhan, China. Since the first of May, China has been recording an average of 17 cases per day. This data’s trend is somewhat linear, though daily case totals have been slightly higher in the most recent two weeks (due to an outbreak in the capital). If we assume the data to be linear with a growth rate of 17 cases per day, by August 20th there will be 86236 cases in China. The average daily case total since the start of July is 29. If the trend is again linear, with 29 cases per day, China will report 86669 cases by August 20th. In order to report fewer than 86,000 cases by August 20th, China needs to record an average of fewer than 10 cases per day. In the past month there have only been 2 days with fewer than 10 cases (2/30). It is therefore very unlikely, (<1%) that 15 of the next 30 days will have fewer than 10 cases.  In order for China to report more than 88,000 cases, it would need to average 64 cases per day. China has not recorded this many infections in a day since April, making this also extremely unlikely. There is one caveat: since January, the Chinese have been accused of manipulating their COVID-19 case data. Because of the inherent unreliability in Chinese data, we need to account for the fact that past cases could come to light that would drastically increase the Chinese case totals. This happened in March, when probable deaths were added to the country’s death total. It is extremely unlikely that the number would be adjusted down, but it could easily be adjusted up. For this reason, I am predicting a 1% likelihood in more than 100,000 cases. Sources:
https://www.economist.com/graphic-detail/2020/04/07/chinas-data-reveal-a-puzzling-link-between-covid-19-cases-and-political-events

Prior: 85,441 cases on July 11th. While there are small outbreaks here and there, the chance of a huge second wave is small, given the measures the country has taken to contain the virus. Thus, the main growth factor for cases would be small outbreaks. Since late April, when everything came back to normal in China, there has been three small yet significant outbreaks in Liaoning, Beijing, and HK (3 in 2.5 months or 1.2 per month). Thus, before Aug. 20th, it's estimated to have another 1.56 cases (1.2*1.3). In each one, the cases have been limited to around 200, so the estimated addition would be 1.56*200 = 312, bringing total number to be 85,753. Reasons for more:
1. HK outbreak seems to be worse than the previous ones. It added 66 new cases today, larger than any one-day addition than the Beijing outbreak. If i'm wrong, this is the most likely surprise factor.
2. Summer travels are up. People are more and more comfortable travelling.
3. International flights are picking up so imported cases can increase. However, this should be limited, as requirements for foreign flights are stringent, and flights with more than 5 confirmed cases would be cancelled for the week after.
4. Second wave? Unlikely, but could have a huge effect on numbers. Reasons for less:
1. Most schools won't be open by Aug 20.
2. People are generally cautious, and almost everyone wears a mask when going outside. Overall, I think less than 86,000 is most likely, followed by 86,000-88,000 if HK outbreak turns out (way) worse. Low probabilities for anything above that because the chance for second wave is low.

85.5k current cases, downwards trend (currently single-digit new cases), and China is quite experienced with the response and is very swift to handle new hotspot emergence.  Due to the thin ranges of the other choice, decide to put more weight for the >100k node. Considering the number of people there, if a cluster pushes the case numbers up it is likely to shoot up more than the 2k bands and therefore put identical weights to each band.

Let me explain my rationale: right now we have 85445 cases in China (which for the WHO includes HK). Excluding HK and punctuated outbreaks, China has been reporting a background of 35-40 cases per week. This background noise will leave us with 85690-85730 cases by the deadline. That is, 270-310 cases away from the limit. The current HK outbreak already includes from 200 to 250 cases. If the outbreak has already reached its peak and somehow manages to be a perfectly symmetric sigmoid curve, there are still 200-250 cases waiting. If it is not a symmetric sigmoid (as in almost every country) ot if we have not reached the peak, then we should expect more cases and we get very easily into the situation that we cross the 86000 cases line. Factor in another small outbreak in China (usually about 100 cases from previous experiences) and we reach again the 86000+ bucket.

Right now the very big question is the current outbreak in Hong Kong, which changes my previous projections of cases to somewhere 85800-86000, with the problem that I am not sure about the evolution of HK. If we add to this the possibility of another small outbreak in another Chinese city, then suddenly it becomes probable to surpass the 86000 mark.

Prior: there are currently 85.4k confirmed cases as of July 9th (that were officially reported). This was during the first wave. A second potential wave is appearing in Beijing, Liaoning and Hebei provinces but the results have thus far double digits and no major uncontrolled spread has occured. My prior is therefore 85,400.  Likelihood: Given China's history of aggressive and draconian lock-downs/contact tracing, their experience containing with the virus, increased PPE supplies and medical advancements since the last wave, I believe the likelihood of the second wave being substantial is very unlikely. The low 000s in flare ups seems to have subsided. This example has demonstrated how quickly China can stamp out any potential flare ups, so between now and August, there can be another 3 flare ups (assuming total infected/flare up = 200) with the total infected staying under 86,000. Given that 1 flare up happened in 4 months since the virus was contained (March - PRESENT), I doubt 3 flare ups will happen between PRESENT - August. Therefore, I will put 75% < 86k and 25% 86k-88k.
Today we have 83,572 and if they have been kept an avg. of 5 cases daily. Government has taken control and implemented necessary tools but still economy is re-open and may surge higher rates.

My argument is based on a steady growth of 40 cases per week, punctuated by a few outbreaks, Shulan/Dongbei and now Beijing, which has already finished for the Gaokao (the exam for university entrance) to be held without problems. If there is no further outbreak and the trend continues, my guess would be about 85500-85700 cases However, Hong Kong opened its border with the mainland about one month ago and we are coincidentally seeing a third wave in HK. This is interesting and I wonder whether from certain assumptions (first and second wave not totally eradicated versus imported cases from the mainland) we could Fermi-estimate the prevalence of the virus in Guangdong province. For that we would need to know how many border crossings have happened from the mainland, which I do not know whether to look at.
